metadata.title: Supramolecular chemistry assisted construction of ultra-stable solvent-resistant membranes for angstrom-sized molecular separation

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Chemical Engineering Journal
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/cej
Supramolecular chemistry assisted construction of ultra-stable solventresistant membranes for angstrom-sized molecular separation
Yanqiu Zhang, Hongguang Sun, Hussain Sadam, Yuyan Liu, Lu Shao⁎
MIIT Key Laboratory of Critical Materials Technology for New Energy Conversion and Storage, State Key Laboratory of Urban Water Resource and Environment, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, China
H I G H L I G H T S
• Supramolecular chemistry was first utilized to construct novel OSN membrane. • A sub-75 nm-thick selective layer was prepared by a one-step “green” process. • The novel membrane has an extraordinary stability in organic solvents. • The OSN membranes exhibited high rejection against angstrom-sized contaminants.
G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
By combining the supramolecular chemistry and membrane science, the biocompatible CD with the inherent cavity (6.0–6.5 Å) and mussel-inspired polydopamine (pDA) can synergistically construct ultra-stable solventresistant membranes for angstrom-sized molecular separations via one-step “green” process.
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Supramolecular chemistry Organic solvent nanofiltration β-Cyclodextrin Dopamine Host-guest interactions Hydrogen-bonds
A B S T R A C T
Organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) membrane is an embryonic technology in chemical engineering for simultaneously purifying organic solvents and recycling nano-scale molecules. Although the inherent nano-cavity cyclodextrins (CDs) as powerful molecular hosts in supramolecular science ensure promise for separation technology, the limited synthesis toolbox and material choice impede the CDs deployment in membrane separations, especially for OSN applications. Herein, biocompatible β-cyclodextrin (β-CD) and mussel-inspired polydopamine (pDA) were discovered as the building blocks to simultaneously construct OSN membranes assisted by the host-guest interactions of supramolecular chemistry and hydrogen-bonds via one-step “green” process. Honeycomb microstructures were formed in this process, which adds the molecular transportation pathways. Such biopolymer membranes can remain extraordinarily stable in organic solvent environments, whilst achieving high rejection against angstrom-sized molecule with different charges toward environmental and energy benefits.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Since the 1970s, the supramolecular chemistry as a new discipline has located at the intersection of biology, chemistry and physics. During
the intersection and integration with other disciplines, the supramolecular chemistry has transformed into the supramolecular science, which is being regarded as one of the important sources to achieve cuttingedge technology and produce new concepts in the 21st century. Three
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2019.04.096 Received 2 February 2019; Received in revised form 10 April 2019; Accepted 14 April 2019
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: shaolu@hit.edu.cn (L. Shao).
Chemical Engineering Journal 371 (2019) 535–543
Available online 15 April 2019 1385-8947/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
new and unique generations with different subjects could be identified as the supramolecular science develops, which are calixarenes, cyclodextrin and crown ester. Due to the influence of supramolecular chemistry, the host-guest supramolecular system reached a higher level, which has been widely used in drug sustained delivery, ion selective electrode, electrochemical biosensor, chemically modified electrode and molecular device [1]. However, the host-guest reaction was seldom investigated in membrane separations, especially for organic solvent nanofiltration.
The organic solvents with highly volatile and lipophilic abilities have the greater poisoning effects, and ameliorating organic solvent detriment on environment has become an important issue urgently requiring the “green” process of industrial solvent system. Organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) membrane are promisingly emerging as the sustainable technology of size-exclusion molecular separation to purify/recycle diverse organic solvents for promising broad usages in petrochemical and pharmaceutical industries [2,3]. OSN greatly relies on the solvent-resistant materials to build “strong” nanoporous membranes that can maintain their separation characteristics with highlyefficiently treating a large range of solvents via the defect free architecture [4]. Therefore, the combination of advanced materials with the deliberate membrane architecture is crucial to obtain OSN membranes with excellent ability for molecular separations and good stability in various solvents for practical applications. On the other hand, β-Cyclodextrin (β-CD) with the inherent cavity (6.0–6.5 Å) is a kind of typical benign molecule in supramolecular chemistry for drug delivery, biomaterials, organic synthesis and separations [5–7]. β-CD as an organic material with suitable cavity has been proven to be a potential candidate to build OSN for creating transporting channels for organic solvent molecules [8]. Moreover, β-CD with such intrinsic micro-porosity are particularly attractive because of their sustainable large-scale production from renewable starch, and inherent nontoxicity [9]. However, the current-available research on β-CD containing nanofiltration membranes inevitably used toxic chemicals such as diamines and acyl chloride, and a large amount of organic solvent via interfacial polymerizations [10], causing serious environmental and toxicological problems. To some extent, this fabrication technique defeats the original purpose of membrane processes for environmental remediation. Most importantly, the host-guest chemistry has been widely reported for β-CDs, but there is no literature to investigate the effect of the hostguest chemistry on OSN membrane formation and resultant membrane performance, which is crucial for advanced membranes [11–14].
Herein, stable OSN membrane with a uniform sub-75 nm-thick selective layer was constructed synergistically by β-CD and mussel-inspired polydopamine (pDA) via one-step “green” process. β-CD was simply mixed into dopamine solution and then immersed porous substrates in ambient conditions without any toxic solvent. Due to the hostguest interaction during membrane formation, β-CD being the subject (the Host) can partially capture monomers/oligomers/pDA nanoparticles to prevent the formation of pDA aggregates resulting in interfacial defects and nonselective voids during the self-polymerization process. The addition of β-CD can rapidly destroy the non-covalent interactions among pDA aggregates to reduce the formation of particles due to the strong hydrogen bonding. Such particle-free coating is beneficial for solvent permeation as the deposited particles would block the ultrafiltration pores and cause a reduction in the solvent permeation flux of nanofiltration membranes. More interestingly, the green pDA/βCD OSN membranes demonstrated exceptional stability in solvents including alcohols, and ketones; whilst obtaining high rejection for angstrom-sized molecular with various charges.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemical and materials
sections.text:
N-methyl-2-pyrrlione (NMP), rose bengal (RB), and dopamine (DA)
were received from Sigma-Aldrich. Methyl blue (MB), methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), acetone, toluene, n-hexane and isopropanol (IPA) were obtained from Tianjin (China). Bromothymol blue (BTB), acid fuchsin (AF), Tris(hydroxymethyl)amino methane (Tris), 1,6-hexanediamine (HDA) and crystal violet (CV) were obtained from Aladdin Industrial Co., Ltd. Deionized water as eco-friendly solvent was homemade.

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of pDA/β-CD OSN membrane
sections.text: Previously we reported the preparations of porous substrates [15]. The biopolymer nanofiltration membrane was prepared in a clean assembly room. 0.2 g dopamine (DA) and 0.6 g β-CD were added to 100mL of Tris buffer solution (pH=8.5, 50 mM). After that, the porous substrate was immersed and gently shaken in the already prepared dip-coating solution for a certain time (1 h, 2 h, 3 h, 4 h, 5 h, 6 h). Finally, the membranes were rinsed with deionized water for five times. In addition, to investigate the influence of varied fabricated condition, the composite membranes composing of different β-CD content (y) and coating time (m) were abbreviated as “pDA/β-CD y-m” when fixing the DA concentrations at 0.2 wt%. If y, m, are not stated, it means that the prepared OSN membrane is obtained by coating DA (0.2 wt%) and β-CD (0.6 wt%) for 3 h. A similar approach was implemented for a control pDA coated sample without any β-CD. For the UV–vis measurements, 100mL Tris solution containing DA (0.2 g) and β-CD (0.6 g) remained stationary for 24 h after 3 h of shock reaction and took the top solution for the UV–vis measurements. The same method was used to prepare βCD (0.6 wt%) solution without DA.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterizations
sections.text: Attenuated total reflection flourier transformed infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) were carried out using a Spectrum One instrument (Perkin Elmer, USA). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was determined using Shimadzu AXIS Ultra DLD with an Al-Kα X-ray source and the photoelectron take-off angle were 90° in regard to the specimen surface. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were collected from Hitachi S-4500. The specimens were fractured by immersing in liquid nitrogen to observe the cross-sectional SEM images. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) images were measured by Solver P47 AFM (Russia). Water contact angles were recorded by a SL 200KB measure system.

sections.heading: 2.4. Permeate flux and rejection tests
sections.text:
The permeation flux of our membrane was conducted on a homemade dead-end nanofiltration. The feed dye solutions (200 ppm) were poured into the measurer with valid membrane test area of 21.2 cm2 and kept stirring at 1000 rpm for reducing the concentration polarization under 5 bar derived from a nitrogen tank. The permeate flux was calculated using Eq. (1): [16]
= ⎛ ⎝ × ⎞ ⎠ ×P V A t 100% (1)
where P corresponds to the permeate flux (Lm−2h−1), V, A and t refer to the volume of permeate, effective membrane area, operation time, respectively.
The OSN membranes’ solute rejections were calculated by Eq. (2): [17]
⎜ ⎟= ⎛ ⎝ − ⎞ ⎠ ×R Cp Cf 1 100% (2)
where R corresponds to rejection, Cp and Cf refer to the concentrations of dyes in permeate and feed solution, which were determined by a UV–vis Cintra20-GBC measurer. The performance of repeated use of
membrane was obtained by the cyclic test. Firstly, the pDA/β-CD membrane was tested for 10 h, then wash the membrane and soak it in alkaline solutions to remove the contamination. After that, continue testing for another 10 h. 10 cycles were tested. Alkaline solutions, which have high capability to dissolve dyes, are widely used to regenerate membranes after fouled by dyes. Thus, a strong alkaline solution (pH=12) was employed to removed contamination from the membrane after the separation process.

sections.heading: 3.1. Physicochemical characteristics of the membrane surfaces
sections.text:
The fabrication procedure of pDA/β-CD membrane was conducted only in aqueous solution at ambient condition without presence of any toxic solvent as shown in Fig. 1. ATR-FTIR spectrum of each fabricated membrane was utilized to detect the variation of functional moieties and mutual interactions on membrane surfaces (Fig. 2a). Pristine porous substrate and pDA coating membranes were tested as contrast. The new peaks located at ∼3315 cm−1 corresponded to the amine –N–H and phenolic –OH stretching vibrations from pDA matrix when compared to that of porous membrane [18,19]. In addition, the components at ∼2936 cm−1 referred to the characteristic stretch peaks of the –CH2– and the peak at ∼1645 and ∼1536 cm−1, which was attributed to the aromatic rings of pDA [20]. After attaching with β-CD, the broader and stronger peaks at∼3315 cm−1 shifted to ∼3276 cm−1 which resulted from the residual hydroxyl groups. The emerged spectrum at ∼1073 cm−1 of the pDA/β-CD membranes referred to the –C–O–C– stretching vibrations of β-CD, which confirmed the immobilization of β-CD on the membrane surfaces with the synergistic effect of pDA. Meanwhile, the peak intensity at ∼1645 cm−1 and ∼3315 cm−1 were the slight shifts, which confirmed the existence of hydrogen bonds in pDA/β-CD membranes [21]. The formation of pDA and pDA/β-CD coating membranes were further verified by the XPS analysis (Fig. 2b and Table 1). The atomic ratios of C/N and O/N of pDA coating membrane were 10.2 and 2.3, respectively, while C/N ratio of pDA/B-CD was 14.5 and O/N ratio was 5.0. The decreased atom percentage of nitrogen and increased intensity of oxygen was due to the hydroxyl groups in β-CD [22]. All the observation indicate that β-CD has been immobilized into membrane surface simply by our one-step
process.

sections.heading: 3.2. Membrane hydrophilicity and surface charges
sections.text: Furthermore, the surface wetting of the OSN membrane has a significant influence on the solvent permeation performance. Hence, we estimated the surface wetting ability using the water contact angle (WCA) measurements (Fig. 2c). The WCA of 52.3° was obtained from the pDA coating membrane, indicating the moderate hydrophilic nature of the pDA polymer. As a comparison, the pDA/β-CD membrane exhibited of a lower WCA with the addition of β-CD [23]. Additionally, increasing β-CD concentrations during the assembly process from 0.2 wt% to 0.6 wt% resulted in the enhancement of WCA from 13.1° to 37.2°. Such phenomenon was probably attributed to the presence of more honeycomb microstructure upon the membrane surface due to the host-guest interactions, resulting in the hydrophobic cavity of β-CD exposed in air as shown in SEM (Fig. 3). The hydrophobic surface will prove to be beneficial to the acceptance of non-polar organic solvents. Nevertheless, with the continued increasing of β-CD from 0.6 wt% to 2 wt%, which led to decrease in WCA [21]. Hydrophilicity and surface rough morphology are two key factors to influence the WCA. According to Wenzel model, the surface of a hydrophilic material with a larger roughness will have a lower contact angle [24], especially for the surface roughness of fabricated membranes which upheld different contents of β-CD, were evaluated by AFM (Table 2). The Ra descend with the ever-increasing β-CD from 0.6 wt% to 2 wt%, which was in accordance with the results of WCA. Furthermore, zeta potential measurements for the pDA and pDA/β-CD composite nanofiltration membranes are shown in Fig. 2d as a function of streaming pH. The zeta potential of the pDA/β-CD nanofiltration membranes increased dramatically owing to host-guest interaction which reduced the deposition of monomers/oligomers/very small pDA on the top of the membrane.

sections.heading: 3.3. Membrane morphologies
sections.text:
The impact of the β-CD dispersion within the mussel-inspired pDA was observed from SEM micrographs. In comparison to pristine porous substrate (Fig. 3a, b), large number of nano-nodules appeared on the surface of the pDA modified membrane (Fig. 3d, e). Besides, the average roughness (Ra) increased from 14.9 nm to 22.1 nm (Fig. 3c and
f), which was attributed to the aggregates of pDA particles during the self-polymerization process via the covalent and noncovalent interactions. Several previous works have reported this phenomenon [25]. As for pDA/β-CD membrane, the surface nano-nodules disappeared whereas the PDA/β-CD honeycomb microstructure appeared on the membrane surface (Fig. 3g and h). Meanwhile, the shrill peaks converted to dull and Ra reduced to 18.6 nm (Fig. 3i). The honeycomb microstructure provided additional molecular transportation pathways for solvent transfer and became beneficial to the separation performance of organic solvent.
3.4. Nanofiltration performance of pDA/β-CD OSN membrane
To engineer the membrane efficiency towards organic solvent, a vast range of solvents were used including methanol (MeOH), ethanol (EtOH), acetone, THF, n-hexane and toluene (Table 3) to demonstrate excellent solvent transportation across our OSN membranes. Fig. 4a exhibited the solvent resistance performance of our pDA/β-CD OSN membrane. For the nonpolar organic solvents, n-hexane and toluene, the permeation flux of pDA/β-CD membrane were 13.6 Lm−2h−1 and 20.2 Lm−2h−1, respectively. The desired permeation flux was mainly ascribed to the occurrence of more honeycomb microstructure on the membrane surface that led to the hydrophobic cavity of β-CD exposed in air. Hydrophobic inner cavity of β-CD holds a strong affinity for nonpolar organic solvents owning to the alkyl (–CH2) groups on inner cavity wall. What is noteworthy that the conventional polyimide composite films manufactured from m-phenylenediamine (MPD) and
trimesoyl chloride (TMC) show almost no permeation flux for n-hexane, which attributes to their higher hydrophilic property [26]. Moreover, the pDA/β-CD OSN membrane also showed extraordinary permeation flux for polar organic solvents (MeOH, EtOH, THF and acetone). The permeation flux followed the tendency of MeOH (36.7 Lm−2h−1) > EtOH (14.9 Lm−2h−1) > THF (12.6 Lm−2h−1) which is opposite to the orders of their kinetic diameters and viscosity [27]. Effect of water (water impurity of common solvents) on the nanofiltration performance was examined. The membrane showed high water permeation flux (40.3 Lm−2h−1) with excellent dye rejection. Compared to our previous work where we crosslinked a pure pDA coating on similar polyimide supports, the addition of β-CD drastically increased EtOH permeation flux by 331%, from 4.6 Lm−2h−1 to 14.9 Lm−2h−1 [28]. The key point to this drastic increase in solvent transport is the absence of polymer crosslinking that usually reduces the fractional free volume content underpinning high solvent permeance in polymer membranes and in formations of honeycomb microstructure molecular transportation pathways [29]. Similarly, acetone had a high permeation flux in this solvent (48.1 Lm−2h−1) because of its low viscosity and small molecular size (0.32 centipoise, CP) [15,30], all solvent permeation fluxes were higher than 12 Lm−2h−1 whilst demonstrating more than 95% MB rejection, which was distinctive from other studies [31] where the additional passageways abated the solute rejection of OSN membranes. In such cases, the benefits of exceptional β-CD additives in OSN membranes were clearly presented. These were possible reasons for the result as shown in Figs. 1 and 3: i). Without adding β-CD, the pDA particles can settle down properly on the surface of the porous substrate. With β-CD, some monomers/oligomers/very small pDA nanoparticles can be captured by β-CD in the suspension and hence unable to sink on the top of membrane. The particle-free coating is beneficial for solvent permeation as the deposited particles would block the ultrafiltration pores and cause a reduction in the solvent permeation flux of nanofiltration membranes. ii) β-CDs can form hostguest complexes with a variety of molecules. Basing on host-guest interactions, in the formation process of pDA layer, the inclusion interaction of β-CD occurs simultaneously, resulting in formation of
honeycomb microstructure molecular transportation pathways. This will facilitate the separation of organic solvents. Meanwhile, the rejection increased due to the strong hydrogen bonding, which promoted self-aggregation of DA and the active layers became much denser. To further confirm the host-guest interaction between pDA and β-CD, UV–vis absorption spectroscopy was used to evidence their interaction process. As shown in the Fig. 4b, there was no discernible absorption peak position in the spectrum of the pure β-CD solution. However,
adding pDA into the β-CD led to two obvious absorption peak appearance at 280 nm and 305 nm for the top solution. These absorption bands could be attributed to the un-polymerized dopamine (280 nm) and its oxidation products such as 5,6-dihydroxyindole as well as pDA oligomers (305 nm) captured by β-CD [32]. The interaction between β-CD and pDA matrices is critical for obtaining high performance OSN membranes with chemical stability.
To hold a better understanding of the effect of surface (top layer) properties on the dyes in organic solvents separation of OSN membrane, the rejections of dyes in organic solvents (EtOH) of the pDA/β-CD membrane and the permeation flux varying different dyes were shown in Fig. 4c. In the process of solvent resistance testing, we selected dye molecules with different molecular volumes and charges (RB, MB, CV, AF and BTB) as the test solutes (Fig. 5). The pDA/β-CD exhibited high rejection (> 90%) to all the solute. For the neutral solute BTB, the rejection was 92.8%, which the size exclusion mechanism principally governed the solute transport property. The order of other solute rejection was RB (98.2%) > MB (97.6%) > AF (95.4%) > CV (90.3%). The combination of Donnan effect and size exclusion effect contributed to the excellent retention towards dyes [36]. In addition, the solvent permeation flux of our membranes outperformed the commercial membranes [37]. Additionally, the structural stability and compaction resistance of the pDA/β-CD OSN membrane with a long-term operation process of continuous filtration for 20 h was assessed (Figs. 4d and 6a). No obvious decrease was observed in the permeation flux and the rejection for MB in acetone, EtOH and water as it benefits from the synergistic effect of DA and β-CD. This separation performance was maintained even after 10 cycles of operation for EtOH/MB (Fig. 6b), which indicates that the pDA/β-CD membrane have better repeatability. In addition, the prepared pDA/β-CD membrane was immersed in solutions with different pH for 12 h, where 0.1mol/L HCl and NaOH were used to adjust the pH, and then the separation performance were tested. Fig. 6c showed that the pDA/β-CD membrane can maintain its
stability while 3 < pH < 12. The enhancement structural stability was favourable of separation performance of the OSN membrane, and played a crucial role in practical applications.
Coating time on membranes will influence the membrane separation performance. Fig. 7a showed the permeation flux and the rejection of the as-prepared composite pDA/β-CD membrane for 200 ppmMB. The permeation flux increased significantly with the pDA coating time enhanced since 1–3 h, which was due to the increased number of
honeycomb microstructure on the active layer over time. Meanwhile, due to the increasing of the layer thickness, the rejection of MB enhanced from 80.8% to 97.6%. Nevertheless, the permeation flux reduced after the coating time extending to 6 h and the rejection remained with only slight changes. Obviously, this should be due to the size sieving effect because of the decreasing in the membrane pore size caused by the anchoring of large number of pDA layer onto the internal wall of pores [38,39]. Therefore, 3 h is the best reaction time after
taking into account the permeation flux and the rejection property for the pDA/β-CD membrane.
The concentration of β-CDs were also crucial for the performance of the OSN membranes [40]. As β-CD can accelerate the polymerization process of DA as well as destroy the non-covalent interactions among pDA aggregates and also occur of host-guest reaction on the membranes’ selective layer [21]. Without β-CD monomer, the general MB rejection of pDA membrane was in a lower level (68.4%) (Fig. 7b). An optimal concentration of β-CDs was required to optimize rejection by minimizing the formation of non-selective voids, whilst preventing macroscopic cracks during membrane fabrication and imbuing chemical stability in organic solvents. With 0.6 wt% β-CD deposition, the pDA/β-CD membrane exhibited further improved general permeation flux from 6.8 Lm−2h−1 (pDA coating) to 14.9 Lm−2h−1 and rejection from 68.4% to 97.3%, which owing to the increasing of honeycomb microstructure and the denser pDA layer. Meanwhile, the thickness was decreased as the β-CD concentration from 0.2 to 2 wt%. It was caused by the host-guest interaction of β-CD and DA, which decreased the deposition of pDA on the membrane surface (Fig. 8). For the 0.6 wt% βCD, the membrane thickness was 75 nm. Nevertheless, when the concentration β-CD was 2 wt%, the permeation flux and rejection reduced, and the thickness decreased to 48 nm. The high concentration of β-CD will hinder and destroy the pDA matrix. The reticular thin layer formed on the membrane surface, reducing the liquid transfer channel.
Furthermore, the rejection reduced due to the formation of defects. Therefore, 0.6 wt% is the optimal condition for β-CD.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, we have developed a new synthesis strategy utilizing biocompatible cyclodextrin (CD) and mussel-inspired pDA to fabricate novel OSN membrane. The host-guest reaction of supramolecular chemistry was first exploited for the formation of the excellent stable selection layer of OSN. The structural stability was enhanced due to their good compatibility which is beneficial for the compaction resistance during long-term filtration process. Even after 20 h of continuous operation, there was no discernible change for MB separation performance (EtOH, 14.9 Lm−2h−1, 97.6%; acetone, 48.1 Lm−2h−1, 95.5%, water, 40.3 Lm−2h−1, 98.2%) of pDA/β-CD membrane. The dense and homogeneous microstructure’s active layer also endow the OSN membrane with high rejections for different dyes in organic solvent. Our designed strategy here is not only environmental friendly because of the used natural materials and the green process, but inspiring the exploration of the host-guest chemistry of supramolecular chemistry for further deployment in advanced membrane separations.

sections.heading: Acknowledgement
sections.text: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21878062, 51573035).

referenceMentions.context: Due to the influence of supramolecular chemistry, the host-guest supramolecular system reached a higher level, which has been widely used in drug sustained delivery, ion selective electrode, electrochemical biosensor, chemically modified electrode and molecular device [1].

Organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) membrane are promisingly emerging as the sustainable technology of size-exclusion molecular separation to purify/recycle diverse organic solvents for promising broad usages in petrochemical and pharmaceutical industries [2,3].

Organic solvent nanofiltration (OSN) membrane are promisingly emerging as the sustainable technology of size-exclusion molecular separation to purify/recycle diverse organic solvents for promising broad usages in petrochemical and pharmaceutical industries [2,3].

OSN greatly relies on the solvent-resistant materials to build “strong” nanoporous membranes that can maintain their separation characteristics with highlyefficiently treating a large range of solvents via the defect free architecture [4].
β-CD as an organic material with suitable cavity has been proven to be a potential candidate to build OSN for creating transporting channels for organic solvent molecules [8].
Moreover, β-CD with such intrinsic micro-porosity are particularly attractive because of their sustainable large-scale production from renewable starch, and inherent nontoxicity [9].

However, the current-available research on β-CD containing nanofiltration membranes inevitably used toxic chemicals such as diamines and acyl chloride, and a large amount of organic solvent via interfacial polymerizations [10], causing serious environmental and toxicological problems.

metadata.abstractText: By combining the supramolecular chemistry and membrane science, the biocompatible CD with the inherent cavity (6.0–6.5 Å) and mussel-inspired polydopamine (pDA) can synergistically construct ultra-stable solventresistant membranes for angstrom-sized molecular separations via one-step “green” process. A R T I C L E I N F O
